zone.line: But my pleasures arose from
the contemplation of nature ^alone, I had no
companion: my warm affections finding
no return from any other human heart
were forced to run waste on inanimate
objects. Sometimes indeed I wept when
my aunt received my caresses with repul-
sive coldness, and when I looked round
and found none to love; but I quickly
dried my tears. As I grew older books in
sone some degree supplied the place of
human intercourse: the library of my
Aunt was very small; Shakespear, Milton;
& Pope and Cowper were the strangley
assorted poets of her collection; and among
the prose authors a translation of Livy
and Rollinâ€™s antient ancient history
were my chief favourites although as
I adva emerged from childhood I found
others highly interesting b which I had
before neglected as dull.
When I was twlev twelve years old
